msContents.summary: Fol. 1a: The acts of Moses. Not identical with the Acts of Moses which form part of the Disciples (see remarks on manuscripts no.6 and 7). The book is a dialogue between God and Moses on Mount Sinai. Moses asks and gets explanations about the recompense for the fulfillment of the commandments and about the punishments for various sins. In the introductory eulogy and in the second colophon the book is styled as "Gadla Muse" = Acts of Moses. But in the first colophon the work is styled as "Nagara Muse" = The words of Moses. In the introductory eulogy and in the second colophon the name of the copyist is given as Abba Anania. This is the name given as copyist also in the Paris manuscript of the collection d"abbadie described by Conti-Rossini under no.220. According to the first colophon, the book has been translated from an Arab original during the reign of the Emperor (Joas I, 1755-1769). -- Fol. 14a. The death of Aaron (Mota Aron). In the colophon the book is styled as "Gadla Aron" = Acts of Aron. According to the introductory eulogy, this is a homily of St. Jacob of Serug pronounced on the Sabbath (or sunday?) commemorating the death of Aaron. The copyist is again Abba Anania. -- Fol. 40a. The acts of Susanna (Gadla Sosena). This was originally a Christian work, praising and illustrating the might of the angels, particularly of Michael and Gabriel. The story of Susanna is only a short episode (fol. 43a-45a). It is virtually the same story as in the apocryphal book of Susanna, but Susanna is here the daughter and the widow of kings and her deliverer is , instead of Daniel, the angel Michael. The Falasha copyist, again Abba Anania, has expurgated all manifest Christian expressions, but he has left such traces as Susanna "signing her face three times with the sign of God". The only trace of this book in other collections of Ethiopic manuscripts seems to be Dillmann's notice on manuscript 69,10 in his Handschriftenverzeichnis der Kgl. Bibliothek in Berlin (Berlin, 1878). But as Dillmann gives there no specimen of the text, no comparison could be made
